> I basically only used checked exceptions because the way I 
> understand it: runtime exceptions are for circumstances that you
can 
> not foresee and therefore can not handle.
This appears to be conventional wisdom, as you've noticed from the
java tutorial.  I disagree wholeheartedly - whether an exception is
foreseable has nothing to do with whether it should be 'checked'; in
fact no api has any business /forcing/ client code to handle a given
exception.  Instead an api should document the exceptions it may
generate and let the client decide whether/where to deal with it.

> To extend the example below with the FileNotFoundException, What is
> the effect of throwing a runtime exception? Will the program 
> terminate with this exception? Also if the name of the file was 
> chosen by the user instead, would it be better to use a checked 
> exception?
The only practical difference with using a runtime exception is that
it doesn't force clients to code a catch for it.  For example, assume
the code in question was within the method:

    public InputStream open() throws FileNotFoundException

This forces all users of the method to write catch blocks.  If we
convert the exception to a RuntimeException, say:

    class RuntimeFileNotFoundException extends RuntimeException {...

And we change openFileInputStream() to:
    public InputStream open() throws RuntimeFileNotFoundException()

Now, client code has a choice: if they are actually going to do
something about the exception, they can catch
RuntimeFileNotFoundException; otherwise, they can just let it
propogate up the call stack (the compiler doesn't force a catch block
for RTEs).

To answer your question about whether your system will terminate
because you used a RTE:  all programs should have some top-level
exception handling code.  The nature of this handler depends on your
context - a web application will respond differently to a batch
processing app.  If a RTE propogates all the way up your callstack, it
should be caught by this handler.

Would i use a checked exception if the user chose the name of the
file? No. Consider two scenarios:
1. The user expected the file to be there: in this case, something has
/already/ gone wrong if the file doesn't exist - find /that/ bug and
fix it instead.  Coding a catch block for something that shouldn't
happen is like lying to cover an earlier lie.
2. The file may or may not exist: this means there are two predictable
outcomes we have to code for.  We should be using an if/else to code
for them.  Using exceptions to control predictable program flow is a
comom code smell and should be avoided.

Neither of the scenarios above requires any exception handling (except
of course the top-level handler).
